statement.text: Aortic root replacement in Marfan syndrome addresses annuloaortic ectasia and aortic regurgitation, traditionally with a composite valve-graft conduit (Bentall procedure) or increasingly with valve-sparing techniques in suitable anatomy.

explanation.intuition: In Marfan syndrome, the aortic root (where the aorta meets the heart) balloons out and stretches the valve, causing it to leak. The fix is to replace the entire root - the dilated tube AND the stretched valve - with a new unit.
explanation.key_insight: Surgical threshold for root replacement in Marfan is 5.0cm (compared to 5.5cm in sporadic aneurysm) or 4.5cm with family history of dissection, rapid growth (>5mm/year), or planned pregnancy.
explanation.technical_details: Bentall procedure: composite mechanical valve-graft, coronary buttons reimplanted. Valve-sparing root replacement: David reimplantation (aortic valve inside graft) or Yacoub remodeling. Selection: Bentall if leaflet pathology, valve-sparing if normal leaflets and experienced surgeon. Thresholds: 5.0cm diameter, 4.5cm if risk factors, 4.0cm if prior type A dissection. Follow-up: annual imaging, lifelong beta-blockade, anticoagulation if mechanical valve.

clinical_features.anticoagulation: Lifelong if mechanical valve (Bentall), not required if valve-sparing

clinical_pearls: Threshold is 5.0cm in Marfan (lower than sporadic aneurysm)
Valve-sparing avoids lifelong anticoagulation if anatomy suitable
Family history of dissection lowers threshold to 4.5cm
